questions.question_text: Which two statements about Node Management Addresses are true? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Node management addresses are configured during the initial APIC and switch setup scripts, and they are not part of APIC policy configuration.
choices.E: The external management entity instance profile communicates with nodes that are part if out-of-band management endpoint group.
choices.A: The managed node connectivity group captures the set of nodes that are going to participate in the management network.
choices.C: Static node management addresses, in-band and out-of-band, are associated with the common tenant.
choices.D: Static node management addresses support only IPv4 addressing.

discussion.content:
C is wrong. Static node management addresses are in tenant mgmt, not in common.
So the best answers are A+E.

questions.question_text: Which two parameters must be identical per interface while configuring virtual port channels. (Choose two.)

discussion.content: What is the difference between Answer A and D ?

questions.question_text: When designing a FabricPath environment, which option is considered best practice for the interface connection type between a set of leaf and spine nodes?

discussion.content:
Configure the ITD Virtual IP Address
The ITD Virtual IP Address (VIP) must be in a different subnet than both the hosts and the nodes:

N7k-1(config-itd)# virtual ip 192.168.30.1 255.255.255.255 advertise enable
The ITD VIP is essentially a dummy interface from the Nexus 7000 perspective - for example, the switch does not respond to ping requests addressed to the VIP. It is used to match traffic against the route map that is automatically created and applied to the ITD ingress interface.

Tip: You will not be able to successfully ping the ITD VIP until the end nodes are configured with the VIP address.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. ITD is configured as shown on a Cisco Nexus 7000 switch. Why is a ping to the VIP address still not working?

choices.C: Fail action is set to the wrong mode.
choices.B: To ping VIP, you must add a probe to the device group.
choices.A: VIP must be from the same subnet as the ingress interface

questions.question_text:
A user requests one primary VLAN, two community VLANs, and two isolated VLANs for multicast capable servers that must transmit multicast traffic and receive multicast traffic through the use of IGMPv2.
On which VLAN must the IGMP querier be configured?

choices.B: Layer 2 multicast is not supported when using private VLANs
choices.C: isolated VLAN and both community VLANs

discussion.content:
Answer: A

Consider the following configuration limitations with other features when configuring IGMP Snooping:

IGMP snooping runs only on the primary VLAN and uses the configuration of the primary VLAN for all secondary VLANs.

Any IGMP snooping join request in the secondary VLAN is treated as if it is received in the primary VLAN.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus5500/sw/layer2/7x/b_5500_Layer2_Config_7x/config_igmp_snooping.html
